TITLE:

   [**9-24**]- 0500: back in wide complex afib/RVR 180s, SBP 70-100 (off
   pressors) --> repleted lytes, amio 150 mg IV followed by gtt +
   diltiazem 10 mg IV.  HR came down to 120-140, SBP ~80.   Extubated.
   Stopped amiodarone and started PO verapamil + quinidine
   Over the course of the day, BP stayed in 110s-120s.  HR stable in
   80s-90s (sinus).  Patient had no major events.  Sat up in chair, diet
   advanced.  Stable with no signs of distress.  In evening, BP up to 150s
   with no symptomatic complaints.  At 2225, BP 123/98 with HR of 98.
   Comfortable.

   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:15.3/36.7/1.3, CK / CKMB /
   Troponin-T:254/23/0.71, Lactic Acid:1.0 mmol/L, Ca++:8.5 mg/dL,
   Mg++:2.1 mg/dL, PO4:3.1 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   Mr [**Known lastname 3369**] is a 63 year-old man with a history of ischemic
   cardiomyopathy s/p ICD/biV pacer and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation who
   presents with atrial fibrillation resulting in ICD firing in the
   setting of missing his rate control agents.  Now in sinus rhythm.
   #) Atrial fibrillation:  Likely triggered by stopping sotalol and
   metoprolol.  Likely the metoprolol had been supressing his sympathetic
   drive recently and prevent recurrent afib.  However, in the setting of
   ambulating on [**9-23**] and no lopressor, he flipped back into it.  Baseline
   rhythm is sinus sensed, v-paced, but pacer turns off at rates >150 and
   his native (LBBB) conduction is exposed.  ICD firing happened because
   of relatively wide complex misrecognized as VT.  He spontaneously
   converted to NSR, reverted to atrial fibrillation, now back in sinus
   tachycardia.
   - holding metoprolol given hypotension experienced on admission.
   - stopped amidarone yesterday and started patient on verapamil and
   quinidine sulfate 200mg PO q6hr
   - tele
   #) Respiratory decompensation:  Pt with history asthma + BOOP,
   initially retaining CO2 on arrival to CCU.  Possibly his broncospasm
   was worsened in the setting of frequent dosing of metoprolol.  He has
   also received repeated doses of Ativan, but his tachypnea argues
   against hypoventilation secondary to depressed drive.  He has also been
   intermittently hypoxic, with questionable aspiration PNA (RLL opacity
   of CXR) +/-some degree of volume overload noted on CXR.  Pt intubated
   on admission to hospital.  Extubated yesterday- did well.  No signs of
   respiratory distress.
   - d/c levo given tendency to prolong QT
   - stopped flagyl given unlikeliness of aspiration PNA
   - on NC- satting well.
   - continue home asthma meds (pulmicort, albuterol, montelukast,
   fluticasone)
   #) Hypotension:  Resolved.  BP now in 140s.
   - phenylephrine PRN hypotension
   - stress-dose steroids
   #) Pump:  No echo in our system, but by report EF 30%.  Some evidence
   of volume overload on initial CXR, but neither cardiogenic shock nor
   pulmonary edema seem to be the main causes of his decompensation.
   - ECHO on [**9-24**] shows moderately dilated left ventricle with severe
   global systolic dysfunction. Increased mitral regurgitation with atrial
   fibrillation and rapid ventricular response (175 bpm).  LVEF of 25-30%.
   # Coronaries:  Reported "heart attack" [**2156**] with PCI but no
   intervention, unknown findings.  Cardiac enzymes added onto peri-code
   labs and severely elevated, but this was in the setting of multiple ICD
   firings.  EKG without ischemic changes.
   - restarted ASA yesterday
   #) Esophageal inflammation:  Per thoracic surgery, he actually never
   had an esophageal tear, only imflammatory changes.  He has been on
   vanc/levo/flagyl/fluconazole and was changed to fluconazole/augmentin
   yesterday in anticipation of discharge.  Diet recently advanced to
   regular but softs
   - d/c
ed fluconazole one day early due to risk of prolonging QT
   - f/u thoracics recs (following as consults)
   FEN: IVFs PRN, monitor and replete lytes PRN, will advance diet as
   tolerated
   ACCESS: PIV's
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with heparin SC
   CODE: full code, confirmed with pt's wife
   [**Name (NI) **]: with patient's wife [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 3369**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8360**] (other numbers on
   board in room)
   DISPO: CCU for now
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   PICC Line - [**2161-9-23**] 04:00 PM
   Multi Lumen - [**2161-9-23**] 11:31 PM
   Arterial Line - [**2161-9-24**] 02:07 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status:
   Disposition:

Based on the provided progress note, the patient, a 63-year-old man with a history of ischemic cardiomyopathy, presents with atrial fibrillation (AF) resulting in ICD firing. The patient was previously in sinus rhythm but developed AF after stopping his rate control agents.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a blood pressure of 133/76 mmHg and a heart rate of 79 bpm. His respiratory rate is 19 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 94%. His physical examination is notable for anxious behavior, tachycardia, and improved breath sounds bilaterally.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 14.8, a hemoglobin level of 9.8 g/dL, and a platelet count of 128. His troponin-T level is 0.71, and his creatinine level is 1.2 mg/dL. His electrocardiogram (ECG) shows a paced rhythm with a heart rate of 79 bpm.

The patient's medical history includes a history of asthma, bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP), and a recent "heart attack" with PCI but no intervention. He has been treated with various medications, including metoprolol, sotalol, and verapamil, and has undergone multiple ICD firings.

The patient's current medications include verapamil, quinidine sulfate, and pantoprazole. He has also been treated with antibiotics, including metronidazole and fluconazole.

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Atrial fibrillation: The patient's AF is likely triggered by stopping his rate control agents. He is currently in sinus rhythm and will be monitored for any further episodes.
* Respiratory decompensation: The patient has a history of asthma and BOOP, and his recent respiratory decompensation may be related to his bronchospasm or volume overload. He will be monitored for any further respiratory distress.
* Hypotension: The patient's hypotension has resolved, and he will be monitored for any further episodes.
* Pump: The patient's left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) is 25-30%, and he has evidence of volume overload on his initial chest X-ray (CXR). He will be monitored for any further signs of cardiogenic shock or pulmonary edema.
* Coronaries: The patient has a history of a recent "heart attack" with PCI but no intervention. He will be monitored for any further signs of ischemia or infarction.
* Esophageal inflammation: The patient has evidence of esophageal inflammation, and he will be monitored for any further signs of esophageal injury.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Atrial fibrillation: The patient may experience further episodes of AF, which could lead to ICD firing or other complications.
* Respiratory decompensation: The patient's respiratory decompensation may worsen, leading to further respiratory distress or failure.
* Hypotension: The patient may experience further episodes of hypotension, which could lead to organ dysfunction or failure.
* Pump failure: The patient's LVEF is 25-30%, and he has evidence of volume overload on his initial CXR. He may experience further signs of cardiogenic shock or pulmonary edema.
* Coronary artery disease: The patient has a history of a recent "heart attack" with PCI but no intervention. He may experience further signs of ischemia or infarction.
* Esophageal injury: The patient has evidence of esophageal inflammation, and he may experience further signs of esophageal injury or perforation.

Overall, the patient is at risk for several medical complications, and close monitoring and management will be necessary to prevent or treat these complications.

   setting of missing his rate control agents.  Now in sinus rhythm.
   #) Atrial fibrillation:  Likely triggered by stopping sotalol and
   metoprolol.  Likely the metoprolol had been supressing his sympathetic
   drive recently and prevent recurrent afib.  However, in the setting of
   ambulating on [**9-23**] and no lopressor, he flipped back into it.  Baseline
   rhythm is sinus sensed, v-paced, but pacer turns off at rates >150 and
   his native (LBBB) conduction is exposed.  ICD firing happened because
   of relatively wide complex misrecognized as VT.  He spontaneously
   converted to NSR, reverted to atrial fibrillation, now back in sinus
   tachycardia.
   - holding metoprolol given hypotension experienced on admission.
   - stopped amidarone yesterday and started patient on verapamil and
   quinidine sulfate 200mg PO q6hr
   - tele
   #) Respiratory decompensation:  Pt with history asthma + BOOP,
   initially retaining CO2 on arrival to CCU.  Possibly his broncospasm
   was worsened in the setting of frequent dosing of metoprolol.  He has
   also received repeated doses of Ativan, but his tachypnea argues
   against hypoventilation secondary to depressed drive.  He has also been
   intermittently hypoxic, with questionable aspiration PNA (RLL opacity
   of CXR) +/-some degree of volume overload noted on CXR.  Pt intubated
   on admission to hospital.  Extubated yesterday- did well.  No signs of
   respiratory distress.
   - d/c levo given tendency to prolong QT
   - stopped flagyl given unlikeliness of aspiration PNA
   - on NC- satting well.
   - continue home asthma meds (pulmicort, albuterol, montelukast,
   fluticasone)
   #) Hypotension:  Resolved.  BP now in 140s-150s.
   - consider restarting some home BP meds (metoprolol, lisinopril).
   - continue verapamil.
   - stress-dose steroids
   #) Pump:  No echo in our system, but by report EF 30%.  Some evidence
   of volume overload on initial CXR, but neither cardiogenic shock nor
   pulmonary edema seem to be the main causes of his decompensation.
   - ECHO on [**9-24**] shows moderately dilated left ventricle with severe
   global systolic dysfunction. Increased mitral regurgitation with atrial
   fibrillation and rapid ventricular response (175 bpm).  LVEF of 25-30%.
   # Coronaries:  Reported "heart attack" [**2156**] with PCI but no
   intervention, unknown findings.  Cardiac enzymes added onto peri-code
   labs and severely elevated, but this was in the setting of multiple ICD
   firings.  EKG without ischemic changes.
   - restarted ASA yesterday
   #) Esophageal inflammation:  Per thoracic surgery, he actually never
   had an esophageal tear, only imflammatory changes.  He has been on
   vanc/levo/flagyl/fluconazole and was changed to fluconazole/augmentin
   yesterday in anticipation of discharge.  Diet recently advanced to
   regular but softs
   - d/c
ed fluconazole one day early due to risk of prolonging QT
   - f/u thoracics recs (following as consults)
   FEN: IVFs PRN, monitor and replete lytes PRN, will advance diet as
   tolerated

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 63-year-old man with a history of ischemic cardiomyopathy, s/p ICD/biV pacer, and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. The patient presented with atrial fibrillation resulting in ICD firing, which was likely triggered by stopping his rate control agents.

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Vital signs: Blood pressure (BP) 133/76 mmHg, heart rate (HR) 79 bpm, respiratory rate (RR) 19 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation (SpO2) 94%.
* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient is receiving IV fluids and has a central venous catheter in place.
* Respiratory support: The patient is receiving continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) and positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) through a ventilator.
* Laboratory results: The patient's white blood cell count (WBC) is 14.8 x 10^9/L, hemoglobin (Hb) is 9.8 g/dL, platelet count (Plt) is 128 x 10^9/L, and creatinine (Cr) is 1.2 mg/dL.
* Medications: The patient is receiving verapamil, quinidine sulfate, and metoprolol, and has been started on pantoprazole and heparin.
* Plan: The patient is to continue to receive verapamil and quinidine sulfate, and to have his BP and HR monitored closely.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may lead to complications such as stroke, heart failure, and cardiac arrest.
* Hypotension: The patient's BP may continue to be unstable, which could lead to complications such as organ failure and death.
* Respiratory decompensation: The patient's respiratory status may deteriorate, leading to complications such as respiratory failure and death.
* Infection: The patient is at risk for developing infections such as pneumonia and sepsis, which could lead to complications such as organ failure and death.
* Bleeding: The patient's bleeding risk is increased due to his anticoagulation therapy, which could lead to complications such as hemorrhage and death.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and to adjust his treatment plan as needed to prevent or manage these potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   Mr [**Known lastname 3369**] is a 63 year-old man with a history of ischemic
   cardiomyopathy s/p ICD/biV pacer and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation who
   presents with atrial fibrillation resulting in ICD firing in the
   setting of missing his rate control agents.  Now in sinus rhythm.
   #) Atrial fibrillation:  Likely triggered by stopping sotalol and
   metoprolol.  Likely the metoprolol had been supressing his sympathetic
   drive recently and prevent recurrent afib.  However, in the setting of
   ambulating on [**9-23**] and no lopressor, he flipped back into it.  Baseline
   rhythm is sinus sensed, v-paced, but pacer turns off at rates >150 and
   his native (LBBB) conduction is exposed.  ICD firing happened because
   of relatively wide complex misrecognized as VT.  He spontaneously
   converted to NSR, reverted to atrial fibrillation, now back in sinus
   tachycardia.
   - holding metoprolol given hypotension experienced on admission.
   - stopped amidarone yesterday and started patient on verapamil and
   quinidine sulfate 200mg PO q6hr
   - tele
   - EKG today
   #) Respiratory decompensation:  Pt with history asthma + BOOP,
   initially retaining CO2 on arrival to CCU.  Possibly his broncospasm
   was worsened in the setting of frequent dosing of metoprolol.  He has
   also received repeated doses of Ativan, but his tachypnea argues
   against hypoventilation secondary to depressed drive.  He has also been
   intermittently hypoxic, with questionable aspiration PNA (RLL opacity
   of CXR) +/-some degree of volume overload noted on CXR.  Pt intubated
   on admission to hospital.  Extubated yesterday- did well.  No signs of
   respiratory distress.
   - d/c levo given tendency to prolong QT
   - stopped flagyl given unlikeliness of aspiration PNA.
   - discontinue augmentin today
   - on RA- satting well.
   - continue home asthma meds (pulmicort, albuterol, montelukast,
   fluticasone)
   #) Hypotension:  Resolved.  BP now in 140s-150s.
   - Restart home lisinopril 20mg PO daily
   - continue verapamil.
   - stress-dose steroids
   #) Pump:  No echo in our system, but by report EF 30%.  Some evidence
   of volume overload on initial CXR, but neither cardiogenic shock nor
   pulmonary edema seem to be the main causes of his decompensation.
   - ECHO on [**9-24**] shows moderately dilated left ventricle with severe
   global systolic dysfunction. Increased mitral regurgitation with atrial
   fibrillation and rapid ventricular response (175 bpm).  LVEF of 25-30%.
   # Coronaries:  Reported "heart attack" [**2156**] with PCI but no
   intervention, unknown findings.  Cardiac enzymes added onto peri-code
   labs and severely elevated, but this was in the setting of multiple ICD
   firings.  EKG without ischemic changes.
   - restarted ASA yesterday
   #) Esophageal inflammation:  Per thoracic surgery, he actually never
   had an esophageal tear, only imflammatory changes.  He has been on
   vanc/levo/flagyl/fluconazole and was changed to fluconazole/augmentin
   yesterday in anticipation of discharge.  Diet recently advanced to
   regular but softs
   - d/c
ed fluconazole one day early due to risk of prolonging QT
   - f/u thoracics recs (following as consults)
   FEN: IVFs PRN, monitor and replete lytes PRN, will advance diet as
   tolerated
   ACCESS: PIV's
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with heparin SC
   CODE: full code, confirmed with pt's wife

Summary:

The patient, a 63-year-old man with a history of ischemic cardiomyopathy, presents with atrial fibrillation (AFib) resulting in ICD firing. He was initially in wide complex AFib with a rapid ventricular response, but was converted to sinus rhythm with amiodarone and diltiazem. He was extubated and advanced to a regular diet. His blood pressure remained stable, and his heart rate was in the 80s-90s. He had no major events and was comfortable.

The patient's respiratory status improved, and he was extubated. His chest X-ray showed questionable aspiration pneumonia (RLL opacity) and some degree of volume overload. He was treated with antibiotics and steroids.

His cardiac function was assessed, and his left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) was found to be 25-30%. He had evidence of volume overload on his initial chest X-ray, but neither cardiogenic shock nor pulmonary edema was the main cause of his decompensation.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's history of AFib and the recent episode may indicate a risk of recurrent AFib, which could lead to ICD firing and potential complications.
2. Respiratory Complications: The patient's history of asthma and bronchiolitis obliterans with organizing pneumonia (BOOP) may increase his risk of respiratory complications, such as pneumonia or respiratory failure.
3. Cardiac Complications: The patient's history of ischemic cardiomyopathy and recent episode of AFib may increase his risk of cardiac complications, such as heart failure or cardiogenic shock.
4. Hypotension: The patient's history of hypotension and recent episode of AFib may increase his risk of recurrent hypotension, which could lead to organ dysfunction.
5. Esophageal Inflammation: The patient's history of esophageal inflammation and recent episode of AFib may increase his risk of esophageal complications, such as perforation or bleeding.
6. Infection: The patient's history of recent antibiotic use and recent episode of AFib may increase his risk of infection, particularly pneumonia or sepsis.
7. QT Prolongation: The patient's history of QT prolongation and recent episode of AFib may increase his risk of torsades de pointes or other arrhythmias.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and adjust treatment as necessary to prevent recurrent AFib.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust treatment as necessary to prevent respiratory complications.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac function and adjust treatment as necessary to prevent cardiac complications.
4. Consider stress-dose steroids to prevent recurrent hypotension.
5. Consider discontinuing fluconazole due to the risk of QT prolongation.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's esophageal status and adjust treatment as necessary to prevent esophageal complications.
7. Consider antibiotics to prevent infection, particularly pneumonia or sepsis.

   of CXR) +/-some degree of volume overload noted on CXR.  Pt intubated
   on admission to hospital.  Extubated yesterday- did well.  No signs of
   respiratory distress.

   - stopped flagyl given unlikeliness of aspiration PNA.
   - discontinue augmentin today

ed fluconazole one day early due to risk of prolonging QT

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 63-year-old man with a history of ischemic cardiomyopathy, s/p ICD/biV pacer, and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. The patient presented with atrial fibrillation resulting in ICD firing in the setting of missing his rate control agents. He has since converted to sinus rhythm.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a blood pressure in the 110s-120s and a heart rate of 80s-90s. He is comfortable and has no signs of distress.

The patient's respiratory status has improved, with improved breath sounds and dry crackles heard at the bases. He is no longer intubated and is breathing spontaneously.

The patient's cardiac status is stable, with a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 25-30% and evidence of volume overload on his initial CXR.

The patient has a history of asthma and bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP), which may have contributed to his respiratory decompensation.

The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, and his liver function tests (LFTs) are mildly elevated.

The patient's medication list includes verapamil, quinidine sulfate, pantoprazole, and heparin.

The patient's plan is to continue on verapamil and quinidine sulfate, and to restart his home medications, including lisinopril, pulmicort, albuterol, montelukast, and fluticasone.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation and the presence of a pacemaker may increase the risk of atrial fibrillation.
2. Respiratory decompensation: The patient's history of asthma and BOOP may increase the risk of respiratory decompensation, particularly if he experiences bronchospasm or aspiration pneumonia.
3. Hypotension: The patient's history of hypotension on admission and the presence of a pacemaker may increase the risk of hypotension.
4. Cardiac tamponade: The patient's history of ICD firing and the presence of a pacemaker may increase the risk of cardiac tamponade.
5. Pneumonia: The patient's history of BOOP and the presence of a pacemaker may increase the risk of pneumonia.
6. Sepsis: The patient's history of BOOP and the presence of a pacemaker may increase the risk of sepsis.
7. Stroke: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and the presence of a pacemaker may increase the risk of stroke.
8. Myocardial infarction: The patient's history of ischemic cardiomyopathy and the presence of a pacemaker may increase the risk of myocardial infarction.

Overall, the patient's condition is stable, but he is at risk for several potential medical complications. Close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and treat these complications.

The patient has been receiving various medications, including heparin, pantoprazole, diltiazem, and verapamil.

1. Worsening of COPD: The patient's chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) may worsen due to the respiratory support and medications being administered.

Further monitoring and management of these potential complications are necessary to ensure the patient's safety and optimal care.

   Mr [**Known lastname 3369**] is a 63 year-old man with a history of ischemic

   presents with atrial fibrillation resulting in ICD firing in the
   setting of missing his rate control agents.  Now in sinus rhythm.
   .
   #) Atrial fibrillation:  Likely triggered by stopping sotalol and
   metoprolol.  Likely the metoprolol had been supressing his sympathetic
   drive recently and prevent recurrent afib.  However, in the setting of
   ambulating on [**9-23**] and no lopressor, he flipped back into it.  Baseline
   rhythm is sinus sensed, v-paced, but pacer turns off at rates >150 and
   his native (LBBB) conduction is exposed.  ICD firing happened because
   of relatively wide complex misrecognized as VT.  He spontaneously
   converted to NSR, reverted to atrial fibrillation, now back in sinus
   tachycardia.
   - holding metoprolol given hypotension experienced on admission.
   - stopped amidarone yesterday and started patient on verapamil and
   quinidine sulfate 200mg PO q6hr
   - tele
   .

   initially retaining CO2 on arrival to CCU.  Possibly his broncospasm
   was worsened in the setting of frequent dosing of metoprolol.  He has
   also received repeated doses of Ativan, but his tachypnea argues
   against hypoventilation secondary to depressed drive.  He has also been
   intermittently hypoxic, with questionable aspiration PNA (RLL opacity
   of CXR) +/-some degree of volume overload noted on CXR.  Pt intubated
   on admission to hospital.  Extubated yesterday- did well.  No signs of
   respiratory distress.
   - d/c levo given tendency to prolong QT

   - on NC- satting well.

   - stress-dose steroids
   .

Based on the provided progress note, here is a summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:

The patient, a 63-year-old man with a history of ischemic cardiomyopathy, atrial fibrillation, and previous ICD implantation, was admitted to the ICU with atrial fibrillation resulting in ICD firing. The patient was initially in atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response, which was managed with amiodarone and diltiazem. The patient's blood pressure was initially low, but responded to fluid resuscitation and vasopressor support. The patient was extubated and sat up in a chair, tolerating a diet advanced to full liquids.

The patient's respiratory status has improved, with improved breath sounds and reduced tachypnea. The patient's oxygen saturation is 94%, and the ABG results show a pH of 7.43, pCO2 of 37 mmHg, and pO2 of 298 mmHg.

The patient's cardiac status has also improved, with the patient now in sinus rhythm. The patient's left ventricular function is moderately impaired, with an estimated ejection fraction of 25-30%. The patient has no evidence of pulmonary edema or cardiogenic shock.

The patient's esophageal inflammation has resolved, and the patient is tolerating a diet advanced to full liquids. The patient's antibiotics have been changed to fluconazole and augmentin, and the patient is scheduled to continue antibiotics until at least August 21.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and the presence of an ICD implantation make them at risk for recurrent atrial fibrillation.
2. Respiratory decompensation: The patient's history of asthma and bronchiolitis obliterans with organizing pneumonia (BOOP) make them at risk for respiratory decompensation.
3. Hypotension: The patient's history of hypotension and the presence of vasopressor support make them at risk for recurrent hypotension.
4. Cardiac failure: The patient's moderately impaired left ventricular function make them at risk for cardiac failure.
5. Esophageal complications: The patient's history of esophageal inflammation and the presence of a nasogastric tube make them at risk for esophageal complications.
6. Infection: The patient's presence of a central line and the use of antibiotics make them at risk for infection.

Recommendations for further management include:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and adjust therapy as necessary.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust therapy as necessary.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's blood pressure and adjust therapy as necessary.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's left ventricular function and adjust therapy as necessary.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's esophageal status and adjust therapy as necessary.
6. Continue to monitor the patient for signs of infection and adjust therapy as necessary.

   Assessment and Plan
   Mr [**Known lastname 3369**] is a 63 year-old man with a history of ischemic
   cardiomyopathy s/p ICD/biV pacer and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation who
   presents with atrial fibrillation resulting in ICD firing in the
   setting of missing his rate control agents.  Now in sinus rhythm.
   #) Atrial fibrillation:  Likely triggered by stopping sotalol and
   metoprolol.  Likely the metoprolol had been supressing his sympathetic
   drive recently and prevent recurrent afib.  However, in the setting of
   ambulating on [**9-23**] and no lopressor, he flipped back into it.  Baseline
   rhythm is sinus sensed, v-paced, but pacer turns off at rates >150 and
   his native (LBBB) conduction is exposed.  ICD firing happened because
   of relatively wide complex misrecognized as VT.  He spontaneously
   converted to NSR, reverted to atrial fibrillation, now back in sinus
   tachycardia.
   - holding metoprolol given hypotension experienced on admission.
   - stopped amidarone yesterday and started patient on verapamil and
   quinidine sulfate 200mg PO q6hr
   - tele
   #) Respiratory decompensation:  Pt with history asthma + BOOP,
   initially retaining CO2 on arrival to CCU.  Possibly his broncospasm
   was worsened in the setting of frequent dosing of metoprolol.  He has
   also received repeated doses of Ativan, but his tachypnea argues
   against hypoventilation secondary to depressed drive.  He has also been
   intermittently hypoxic, with questionable aspiration PNA (RLL opacity
   of CXR) +/-some degree of volume overload noted on CXR.  Pt intubated
   on admission to hospital.  Extubated yesterday- did well.  No signs of
   respiratory distress.
   - d/c levo given tendency to prolong QT
   - stopped flagyl given unlikeliness of aspiration PNA
   - on NC- satting well.
   - continue home asthma meds (pulmicort, albuterol, montelukast,
   fluticasone)
   #) Hypotension:  Resolved.  BP now in 140s.
   - phenylephrine PRN hypotension
   - stress-dose steroids
   #) Pump:  No echo in our system, but by report EF 30%.  Some evidence
   of volume overload on initial CXR, but neither cardiogenic shock nor
   pulmonary edema seem to be the main causes of his decompensation.
   - ECHO on [**9-24**] shows moderately dilated left ventricle with severe
   global systolic dysfunction. Increased mitral regurgitation with atrial
   fibrillation and rapid ventricular response (175 bpm).  LVEF of 25-30%.
   # Coronaries:  Reported "heart attack" [**2156**] with PCI but no
   intervention, unknown findings.  Cardiac enzymes added onto peri-code
   labs and severely elevated, but this was in the setting of multiple ICD
   firings.  EKG without ischemic changes.
   - restarted ASA yesterday
   #) Esophageal inflammation:  Per thoracic surgery, he actually never
   had an esophageal tear, only imflammatory changes.  He has been on
   vanc/levo/flagyl/fluconazole and was changed to fluconazole/augmentin
   yesterday in anticipation of discharge.  Diet recently advanced to
   regular but softs
   - d/c
ed fluconazole one day early due to risk of prolonging QT
   - f/u thoracics recs (following as consults)
   FEN: IVFs PRN, monitor and replete lytes PRN, will advance diet as
   tolerated
   ACCESS: PIV's
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with heparin SC
   CODE: full code, confirmed with pt's wife
   [**Name (NI) **]: with patient's wife [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 3369**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8360**] (other numbers on

Summary:

The patient, a 63-year-old man with a history of ischemic cardiomyopathy, atrial fibrillation, and implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD), was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with atrial fibrillation and ICD firing. He was previously intubated due to respiratory decompensation, but was extubated yesterday. The patient's condition has stabilized, with his blood pressure (BP) in the 140s, heart rate (HR) in the 80s-90s, and oxygen saturation (SpO2) of 94%. He is currently on verapamil and quinidine sulfate for rate control and conversion to sinus rhythm.

Potential medical complications:

1. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation is likely to continue, and measures should be taken to prevent ICD firing and maintain sinus rhythm.
2. Respiratory decompensation: The patient's history of asthma and bronchiolitis obliterans with organizing pneumonia (BOOP) increases his risk of respiratory decompensation. Close monitoring of his respiratory status is necessary to prevent further complications.
3. Hypotension: The patient's BP has stabilized, but he is still at risk of hypotension due to his underlying cardiac condition and medication regimen.
4. Pump failure: The patient's left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) is severely decreased, which increases his risk of pump failure and cardiogenic shock.
5. Coronary artery disease: The patient's reported "heart attack" and PCI without intervention may have caused damage to his coronary arteries, increasing his risk of further cardiac events.
6. Esophageal inflammation: The patient's history of esophageal inflammation and recent advancement of his diet may increase his risk of further complications, such as esophageal perforation or bleeding.
7. DVT and VAP prophylaxis: The patient is at risk of developing deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and prophylactic measures should be taken to prevent these complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue verapamil and quinidine sulfate to maintain sinus rhythm and rate control.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and provide respiratory support as needed.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's BP and adjust his medication regimen as necessary to prevent hypotension.
4. Consider further cardiac testing, such as echocardiography or cardiac catheterization, to assess the patient's cardiac function and coronary artery disease.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's esophageal inflammation and adjust his diet and medication regimen as necessary to prevent further complications.
6. Provide prophylactic measures to prevent DVT and VAP, such as heparin and stress-dose steroids.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac enzymes and adjust his medication regimen as necessary to prevent further cardiac complications.

   setting of missing his rate control agents.  Now in sinus rhythm.
   #) Atrial fibrillation:  Likely triggered by stopping sotalol and
   metoprolol.  Likely the metoprolol had been supressing his sympathetic
   drive recently and prevent recurrent afib.  However, in the setting of
   ambulating on [**9-23**] and no lopressor, he flipped back into it.  Baseline
   rhythm is sinus sensed, v-paced, but pacer turns off at rates >150 and
   his native (LBBB) conduction is exposed.  ICD firing happened because
   of relatively wide complex misrecognized as VT.  He spontaneously
   converted to NSR, reverted to atrial fibrillation, now back in sinus
   tachycardia.
   - holding metoprolol given hypotension experienced on admission.
   - stopped amidarone yesterday and started patient on verapamil and
   quinidine sulfate 200mg PO q6hr
   - tele
   - EKG today
   #) Respiratory decompensation:  Pt with history asthma + BOOP,
   initially retaining CO2 on arrival to CCU.  Possibly his broncospasm
   was worsened in the setting of frequent dosing of metoprolol.  He has
   also received repeated doses of Ativan, but his tachypnea argues
   against hypoventilation secondary to depressed drive.  He has also been
   intermittently hypoxic, with questionable aspiration PNA (RLL opacity
   of CXR) +/-some degree of volume overload noted on CXR.  Pt intubated
   on admission to hospital.  Extubated yesterday- did well.  No signs of
   respiratory distress.
   - d/c levo given tendency to prolong QT
   - stopped flagyl given unlikeliness of aspiration PNA.
   - discontinue augmentin today
   - on RA- satting well.
   - continue home asthma meds (pulmicort, albuterol, montelukast,
   fluticasone)
   #) Hypotension:  Resolved.  BP now in 140s-150s.
   - Restart home lisinopril 20mg PO daily
   - continue verapamil.
   - stress-dose steroids
   #) Pump:  No echo in our system, but by report EF 30%.  Some evidence
   of volume overload on initial CXR, but neither cardiogenic shock nor
   pulmonary edema seem to be the main causes of his decompensation.
   - ECHO on [**9-24**] shows moderately dilated left ventricle with severe
   global systolic dysfunction. Increased mitral regurgitation with atrial
   fibrillation and rapid ventricular response (175 bpm).  LVEF of 25-30%.
   # Coronaries:  Reported "heart attack" [**2156**] with PCI but no
   intervention, unknown findings.  Cardiac enzymes added onto peri-code
   labs and severely elevated, but this was in the setting of multiple ICD
   firings.  EKG without ischemic changes.
   - restarted ASA yesterday
   #) Esophageal inflammation:  Per thoracic surgery, he actually never
   had an esophageal tear, only imflammatory changes.  He has been on
   vanc/levo/flagyl/fluconazole and was changed to fluconazole/augmentin
   yesterday in anticipation of discharge.  Diet recently advanced to
   regular but softs
   - d/c
ed fluconazole one day early due to risk of prolonging QT
   - f/u thoracics recs (following as consults)
   FEN: IVFs PRN, monitor and replete lytes PRN, will advance diet as
   tolerated

Based on the patient's daily progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications are noted:

Summary:

The patient, a 63-year-old man with a history of ischemic cardiomyopathy, presents with atrial fibrillation (AFib) resulting in ICD firing. He was initially in sinus rhythm but converted to AFib due to stopping rate control agents. He has been ambulating and has been experiencing respiratory decompensation, hypotension, and esophageal inflammation. He has been treated with various medications, including verapamil, quinidine, and ASA, and has undergone several interventions, including echocardiography and thoracic surgery.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's AFib may lead to complications such as stroke, heart failure, and increased risk of cardiovascular mortality.
2. Respiratory Complications: The patient's respiratory decompensation may lead to complications such as pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and respiratory failure.
3. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may lead to complications such as shock, organ dysfunction, and increased risk of mortality.
4. Esophageal Complications: The patient's esophageal inflammation may lead to complications such as esophageal perforation, esophageal strictures, and increased risk of mortality.
5. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's history of ischemic cardiomyopathy and recent ICD firing may lead to complications such as heart failure, cardiogenic shock, and increased risk of cardiovascular mortality.
6. Infection: The patient's history of pneumonia and recent antibiotic use may lead to complications such as sepsis, septic shock, and increased risk of mortality.
7. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's history of esophageal inflammation and recent antibiotic use may lead to complications such as gastrointestinal bleeding, gastrointestinal perforation, and increased risk of mortality.
8. Neurological Complications: The patient's history of recent ICD firing and recent antibiotic use may lead to complications such as seizures, encephalopathy, and increased risk of mortality.

Overall, the patient is at high risk for complications due to his underlying medical conditions and recent interventions. Close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and treat potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   Mr [**Known lastname 3369**] is a 63 year-old man with a history of ischemic
   cardiomyopathy s/p ICD/biV pacer and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation who
   presents with atrial fibrillation resulting in ICD firing in the
   setting of missing his rate control agents.  Now in sinus rhythm.
   #) Atrial fibrillation:  Likely triggered by stopping sotalol and
   metoprolol.  Likely the metoprolol had been supressing his sympathetic
   drive recently and prevent recurrent afib.  However, in the setting of
   ambulating on [**9-23**] and no lopressor, he flipped back into it.  Baseline
   rhythm is sinus sensed, v-paced, but pacer turns off at rates >150 and
   his native (LBBB) conduction is exposed.  ICD firing happened because
   of relatively wide complex misrecognized as VT.  He spontaneously
   converted to NSR, reverted to atrial fibrillation, now back in sinus
   tachycardia.
   - holding metoprolol given hypotension experienced on admission.
   - stopped amidarone yesterday and started patient on verapamil and
   quinidine sulfate 200mg PO q6hr
   - tele
   - EKG today
   #) Respiratory decompensation:  Pt with history asthma + BOOP,
   initially retaining CO2 on arrival to CCU.  Possibly his broncospasm
   was worsened in the setting of frequent dosing of metoprolol.  He has
   also received repeated doses of Ativan, but his tachypnea argues
   against hypoventilation secondary to depressed drive.  He has also been
   intermittently hypoxic, with questionable aspiration PNA (RLL opacity
   of CXR) +/-some degree of volume overload noted on CXR.  Pt intubated
   on admission to hospital.  Extubated yesterday- did well.  No signs of
   respiratory distress.
   - d/c levo given tendency to prolong QT
   - stopped flagyl given unlikeliness of aspiration PNA.
   - discontinue augmentin today
   - on RA- satting well.
   - continue home asthma meds (pulmicort, albuterol, montelukast,
   fluticasone)
   #) Hypotension:  Resolved.  BP now in 140s-150s.
   - Restart home lisinopril 20mg PO daily
   - continue verapamil.
   - stress-dose steroids
   #) Pump:  No echo in our system, but by report EF 30%.  Some evidence
   of volume overload on initial CXR, but neither cardiogenic shock nor
   pulmonary edema seem to be the main causes of his decompensation.
   - ECHO on [**9-24**] shows moderately dilated left ventricle with severe
   global systolic dysfunction. Increased mitral regurgitation with atrial
   fibrillation and rapid ventricular response (175 bpm).  LVEF of 25-30%.
   # Coronaries:  Reported "heart attack" [**2156**] with PCI but no
   intervention, unknown findings.  Cardiac enzymes added onto peri-code
   labs and severely elevated, but this was in the setting of multiple ICD
   firings.  EKG without ischemic changes.
   - restarted ASA yesterday
   #) Esophageal inflammation:  Per thoracic surgery, he actually never
   had an esophageal tear, only imflammatory changes.  He has been on
   vanc/levo/flagyl/fluconazole and was changed to fluconazole/augmentin
   yesterday in anticipation of discharge.  Diet recently advanced to
   regular but softs
   - d/c
ed fluconazole one day early due to risk of prolonging QT
   - f/u thoracics recs (following as consults)
   FEN: IVFs PRN, monitor and replete lytes PRN, will advance diet as
   tolerated

Based on the provided progress note, the patient, a 63-year-old man with a history of ischemic cardiomyopathy, has been stable in the ICU. The patient has been intermittently in sinus rhythm, but mostly in wide complex atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR). The patient's QTc interval has increased slightly, but remains within normal limits.

The patient has been ambulating and has shown improvement in respiratory status, with improved breath sounds and decreased respiratory distress. The patient's hemodynamic monitoring shows a stable blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygen saturation.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin and creatine kinase (CK) levels, indicating possible myocardial infarction. The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, and his platelet count is low. The patient's liver enzymes are mildly elevated, and his electrolyte levels are within normal limits.

The patient's medical history includes asthma, bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP), and a history of ischemic cardiomyopathy with an implanted cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) and bi-ventricular pacemaker.

Potential medical complications that may arise based on the patient's condition include:

1. Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, which can lead to tachycardia-induced cardiomyopathy and decreased cardiac output.
2. Respiratory decompensation, which can occur due to the patient's history of asthma and BOOP, as well as possible aspiration pneumonia.
3. Hypotension, which can occur due to the patient's history of hypertension and potential cardiac compromise.
4. Myocardial infarction, which is indicated by the elevated troponin and CK levels.
5. Sepsis, which can occur due to the patient's elevated white blood cell count and possible infection.
6. Bleeding complications, which can occur due to the patient's low platelet count.
7. Electrolyte imbalances, which can occur due to the patient's history of cardiac medications and possible electrolyte abnormalities.
8. Cardiovascular instability, which can occur due to the patient's history of cardiac disease and potential cardiac compromise.

The patient's treatment plan includes continuing verapamil and quinidine sulfate, restarting home medications, and monitoring for potential complications. The patient's family has been informed of his condition and treatment plan.

Summary:

The patient is a 63-year-old man with a history of ischemic cardiomyopathy, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, and ICD/biV pacer. He was admitted to the ICU due to atrial fibrillation resulting in ICD firing, likely triggered by stopping rate control agents. He has been experiencing wide complex atrial fibrillation with RVR, and his baseline rhythm is sinus sensed, v-paced. He has been treated with verapamil and quinidine gluconate, and his EKG shows a slight increase in QTc. He has also been experiencing respiratory decompensation, hypotension, and esophageal inflammation. His cardiac enzymes are severely elevated, and his LVEF is 25-30%. He has a history of asthma, BOOP, and "heart attack" with PCI but no intervention.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac complications:
	* Atrial fibrillation with RVR can lead to cardiac arrhythmias, decreased cardiac output, and increased risk of stroke.
	* The patient's history of ischemic cardiomyopathy and ICD/biV pacer increases his risk of cardiac complications.
	* The patient's LVEF of 25-30% indicates severe global systolic dysfunction, which can lead to heart failure and decreased cardiac output.
2. Respiratory complications:
	* The patient's history of asthma and BOOP increases his risk of respiratory decompensation, including acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and respiratory failure.
	* The patient's tachypnea and hypoxia can lead to respiratory acidosis and increased risk of respiratory failure.
3. Gastrointestinal complications:
	* The patient's esophageal inflammation and history of "heart attack" with PCI but no intervention increase his risk of gastrointestinal complications, including esophageal perforation and gastrointestinal bleeding.
4. Neurological complications:
	* The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and ICD firing can lead to neurological complications, including stroke and seizures.
	* The patient's elevated cardiac enzymes can indicate cardiac damage and increase his risk of neurological complications.
5. Infection complications:
	* The patient's history of pneumonia and BOOP increases his risk of infection, including sepsis and septic shock.
	* The patient's elevated white blood cell count and C-reactive protein indicate an active infection and increase his risk of infection complications.

TITLE:
   Chief Complaint:
   24 Hour Events:
   Patient had brief episode of Afib with RVR this AM up to 170s. Patient

   Assessment and Plan
   Mr [**Known lastname 3369**] is a 63 year-old man with a history of ischemic
   cardiomyopathy s/p ICD/biV pacer and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation who
   presents with atrial fibrillation resulting in ICD firing in the
   setting of missing his rate control agents.  In sinus rhythm overnight,
   but going into wide complex atrial fib with RVR.
   #) Atrial fibrillation:  Likely triggered by stopping sotalol and
   metoprolol.  Likely the metoprolol had been supressing his sympathetic
   drive recently and prevent recurrent afib.  However, in the setting of
   ambulating on [**9-23**] and no lopressor, he flipped back into it.  Baseline
   rhythm is sinus sensed, v-paced, but pacer turns off at rates >150 and
   his native (LBBB) conduction is exposed.  ICD firing happened because
   of relatively wide complex misrecognized as VT.  He spontaneously
   converted to NSR, reverted to atrial fibrillation, now alternating
   between the two.
   - stopped amidarone yesterday and started patient on verapamil and
   quinidine gluconate 324 q8 hours
   - tele
   - EKG today
   - will call EP today and discuss quinidine vs. sotalol Rx
   #) Respiratory decompensation:  Pt with history asthma + BOOP,
   initially retaining CO2 on arrival to CCU.  Possibly his broncospasm
   was worsened in the setting of frequent dosing of metoprolol.  He has
   also received repeated doses of Ativan, but his tachypnea argues
   against hypoventilation secondary to depressed drive.  He has also been
   intermittently hypoxic, with questionable aspiration PNA (RLL opacity
   of CXR) +/-some degree of volume overload noted on CXR.  Pt intubated
   on admission to hospital.  Extubated yesterday- did well.  No signs of
   respiratory distress.
   - now off levo given tendency to prolong QT
   - stopped flagyl given unlikeliness of aspiration PNA.
   - discontinued augmentin
   - on RA- satting well.
   - continue home asthma meds (pulmicort, albuterol, montelukast,
   fluticasone)
   #) Hypotension:  Resolved.  BP now in 120s-140s.
   - Restarted home lisinopril 20mg PO daily
   - continue verapamil.
   - stress-dose steroids
   #) Pump:  No echo in our system, but by report EF 30%.  Some evidence
   of volume overload on initial CXR, but neither cardiogenic shock nor
   pulmonary edema seem to be the main causes of his decompensation.
   - ECHO on [**9-24**] shows moderately dilated left ventricle with severe
   global systolic dysfunction. Increased mitral regurgitation with atrial
   fibrillation and rapid ventricular response (175 bpm).  LVEF of 25-30%.
   # Coronaries:  Reported "heart attack" [**2156**] with PCI but no
   intervention, unknown findings.  Cardiac enzymes added onto peri-code
   labs and severely elevated, but this was in the setting of multiple ICD
   firings.  EKG without ischemic changes.
   - restarted ASA yesterday
   #) Esophageal inflammation:  Per thoracic surgery, he actually never
   had an esophageal tear, only imflammatory changes.  He has been on
   vanc/levo/flagyl/fluconazole and now off Abx.  Diet recently advanced
   to regular but softs
   - d/c
ed fluconazole one day early due to risk of prolonging QT
   - f/u thoracics recs (following as consults)
   FEN: IVFs PRN, monitor and replete lytes PRN, will advance diet as
   tolerated
   ACCESS: PIV's
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with heparin SC
   CODE: full code, confirmed with pt's wife
   [**Name (NI) **]: with patient's wife [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 3369**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8360**] (other numbers on

Based on the patient's daily progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications are noted:

Summary:

The patient is a 63-year-old man with a history of ischemic cardiomyopathy, s/p ICD/biV pacer, and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. He presented with atrial fibrillation resulting in ICD firing in the setting of missing his rate control agents. He was initially intubated due to respiratory decompensation, but was extubated yesterday. He has been experiencing episodes of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and his blood pressure has been fluctuating. He has been prescribed verapamil and quinidine gluconate to control his atrial fibrillation.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Complications:
	* Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response may lead to cardiac decompensation, heart failure, or even cardiac arrest.
	* The patient's history of ischemic cardiomyopathy and ICD firing increases the risk of cardiac complications.
	* The patient's blood pressure fluctuations may indicate hypotension or hypertension, which can lead to cardiac complications.
2. Respiratory Complications:
	* The patient's history of asthma and bronchiolitis obliterans with organizing pneumonia (BOOP) increases the risk of respiratory decompensation.
	* The patient's intermittent hypoxia and tachypnea may indicate respiratory failure or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
3. Gastrointestinal Complications:
	* The patient's history of esophageal inflammation and inflammatory changes increases the risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as esophagitis or gastrointestinal bleeding.
4. Infection Complications:
	* The patient's history of pneumonia and sepsis increases the risk of infection complications, such as septic shock or multi-organ failure.
5. Hematological Complications:
	* The patient's anemia of chronic disease and thrombocytopenia increase the risk of bleeding complications or thrombotic events.

Overall, the patient's complex medical history and current condition increase the risk of various medical complications. Close monitoring and management of his condition are essential to prevent or mitigate these complications.

   #) Respiratory decompensation:  Pt with history asthma + BOOP,
   initially retaining CO2 on arrival to CCU.  Possibly his broncospasm
   was worsened in the setting of frequent dosing of metoprolol.  He has
   also received repeated doses of Ativan, but his tachypnea argues
   against hypoventilation secondary to depressed drive.  He has also been
   intermittently hypoxic, with questionable aspiration PNA (RLL opacity
   of CXR) +/-some degree of volume overload noted on CXR.  Pt intubated
   on admission to hospital.  Extubated yesterday- did well.  No signs of
   respiratory distress.
   - now off levo given tendency to prolong QT
   - stopped flagyl given unlikeliness of aspiration PNA.
   - discontinued augmentin
   - on RA- satting well.
   - continue home asthma meds (pulmicort, albuterol, montelukast,
   fluticasone)
   #) Hypotension:  Resolved.  BP now in 120s-140s.
   - Restarted home lisinopril 20mg PO daily
   - continue verapamil and start metoprolol 25mg today
   - stress-dose steroids
   #) Pump:  No echo in our system, but by report EF 30%.  Some evidence
   of volume overload on initial CXR, but neither cardiogenic shock nor
   pulmonary edema seem to be the main causes of his decompensation.
   -          ECHO on [**9-24**] shows moderately dilated left ventricle with
   severe global systolic dysfunction. Increased mitral regurgitation with
   atrial fibrillation and rapid ventricular response (175 bpm).  LVEF of
   25-30%.
   -          Lasix 20mg IV for diuresis yesterday and will give Lasix
   40mg PO dose today with the goal of making the patient 500cc negative;
   Will need lasix 20mg PO daily at home
   # Coronaries:  Reported "heart attack" [**2156**] with PCI but no
   intervention, unknown findings.  Cardiac enzymes added onto peri-code
   labs and severely elevated, but this was in the setting of multiple ICD
   firings.  EKG without ischemic changes.
   - on ASA
   #) Esophageal inflammation:  Per thoracic surgery, he actually never
   had an esophageal tear, only imflammatory changes.  He has been on
   vanc/levo/flagyl/fluconazole and now off Abx.  Diet recently advanced
   to regular but softs
   - d/c
ed fluconazole one day early due to risk of prolonging QT
   - f/u thoracics recs (following as consults)

Summary:

The patient, a 63-year-old man with a history of ischemic cardiomyopathy, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, and ICD/biV pacer, presented to the ICU with atrial fibrillation resulting in ICD firing due to missing rate control agents. The patient's baseline rhythm is sinus sensed, v-paced, but the pacer turns off at rates >150, exposing native conduction. The patient was given verapamil and quinidine gluconate, and metoprolol was restarted to better control his rate and sympathetic drive. The patient's respiratory status has been decompensating, with a history of asthma and BOOP, and has been intubated and extubated. The patient has also had hypotension, which has resolved, and is receiving stress-dose steroids. The patient's cardiac function is moderately impaired, with an EF of 25-30%, and is receiving diuresis with Lasix.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may continue to be a concern, and the patient may require further treatment to control his heart rate and rhythm.
2. Respiratory decompensation: The patient's respiratory status may continue to deteriorate, and the patient may require further treatment, such as non-invasive ventilation or intubation.
3. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may recur, and the patient may require further treatment, such as vasopressors or fluid administration.
4. Cardiac function: The patient's cardiac function is moderately impaired, and the patient may require further treatment, such as cardiac medications or cardiac catheterization.
5. Infection: The patient has a history of esophageal inflammation and has been receiving antibiotics, and the patient may be at risk for further infection.
6. Thromboembolism: The patient is at risk for thromboembolism due to his history of atrial fibrillation and his current anticoagulation therapy.
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's esophageal inflammation and recent antibiotics may increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's atrial fibrillation and adjust treatment as necessary.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust treatment as necessary.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's hypotension and adjust treatment as necessary.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac function and adjust treatment as necessary.
5. Continue to monitor the patient for signs of infection and adjust treatment as necessary.
6. Continue to monitor the patient for signs of thromboembolism and adjust treatment as necessary.
7. Continue to monitor the patient for signs of gastrointestinal bleeding and adjust treatment as necessary.

Plan:

   Mr [**Known lastname 3369**] is a 63 year-old man with a history of ischemic
   cardiomyopathy s/p ICD/biV pacer and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation who
   presents with atrial fibrillation resulting in ICD firing in the
   setting of missing his rate control agents.  In sinus rhythm overnight,
   but going into wide complex atrial fib with RVR.
   #) Atrial fibrillation:  Likely triggered by stopping sotalol and
   metoprolol.  Likely the metoprolol had been supressing his sympathetic
   drive recently and prevent recurrent afib.  However, in the setting of
   ambulating on [**9-23**] and no lopressor, he flipped back into it.  Baseline
   rhythm is sinus sensed, v-paced, but pacer turns off at rates >150 and
   his native (LBBB) conduction is exposed.  ICD firing happened because
   of relatively wide complex misrecognized as VT.  He spontaneously
   converted to NSR, reverted to atrial fibrillation, now alternating
   between the two.
   - on verapamil and quinidine gluconate- increased quinidine gluconate
   from q8 to q6hr
   - continue IV verapamil when patient goes into elevated rate
   - Will start metoprolol 25mg [**Hospital1 **] this AM to better control his rate and
   sympathetic drive
   - Daily EKGs to monitor QTc on quinidine
   - on telemetry
   .
   #) Respiratory decompensation:  Pt with history asthma + BOOP,
   initially retaining CO2 on arrival to CCU.  Possibly his broncospasm
   was worsened in the setting of frequent dosing of metoprolol.  He has
   also received repeated doses of Ativan, but his tachypnea argues
   against hypoventilation secondary to depressed drive.  He has also been
   intermittently hypoxic, with questionable aspiration PNA (RLL opacity
   of CXR) +/-some degree of volume overload noted on CXR.  Pt intubated
   on admission to hospital.  Extubated yesterday- did well.  No signs of
   respiratory distress.
   - now off levo given tendency to prolong QT
   - stopped flagyl given unlikeliness of aspiration PNA.
   - discontinued augmentin
   - on RA- satting well.
   - continue home asthma meds (pulmicort, albuterol, montelukast,
   fluticasone)
   #) Hypotension:  Resolved.  BP now in 120s-140s.
   - Restarted home lisinopril 20mg PO daily
   - continue verapamil and start metoprolol 25mg today
   - stress-dose steroids
   #) Pump:  No echo in our system, but by report EF 30%.  Some evidence
   of volume overload on initial CXR, but neither cardiogenic shock nor
   pulmonary edema seem to be the main causes of his decompensation.
   -          ECHO on [**9-24**] shows moderately dilated left ventricle with
   severe global systolic dysfunction. Increased mitral regurgitation with
   atrial fibrillation and rapid ventricular response (175 bpm).  LVEF of
   25-30%.
   -          Lasix 20mg IV for diuresis yesterday and will give Lasix
   40mg PO dose today with the goal of making the patient 500cc negative;
   Will need lasix 20mg PO daily at home
   # Coronaries:  Reported "heart attack" [**2156**] with PCI but no
   intervention, unknown findings.  Cardiac enzymes added onto peri-code
   labs and severely elevated, but this was in the setting of multiple ICD
   firings.  EKG without ischemic changes.
   - on ASA
   #) Esophageal inflammation:  Per thoracic surgery, he actually never
   had an esophageal tear, only imflammatory changes.  He has been on
   vanc/levo/flagyl/fluconazole and now off Abx.  Diet recently advanced
   to regular but softs
   - d/c
ed fluconazole one day early due to risk of prolonging QT
   - f/u thoracics recs (following as consults)
   FEN: Monitor and replete lytes PRN, cardiac/diabetic diet

   -DVT ppx with heparin SC

Based on the provided physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 63-year-old man with a history of ischemic cardiomyopathy, s/p ICD/biV pacer, and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. The patient presents with atrial fibrillation resulting in ICD firing in the setting of missing his rate control agents.

The patient has had several episodes of atrial fibrillation, including one episode this morning that responded to verapamil. The patient's heart rate has been variable, ranging from 68-144 beats per minute.

The patient has also had respiratory decompensation, with tachypnea and hypoxia. He was intubated on admission to the hospital, but was extubated yesterday without any signs of respiratory distress. The patient is currently on RA and is saturating well.

The patient's blood pressure has been variable, ranging from 120-140 mmHg. He has been restarted on his home lisinopril and will also start metoprolol today.

The patient's cardiac enzymes have been elevated, but this was in the setting of multiple ICD firings. His EKG has been normal without any signs of ischemic changes.

The patient has also had esophageal inflammation, which has responded to treatment with vanc/levo/flagyl/fluconazole. He is currently on a soft diet and is being monitored for any signs of bleeding.

The patient's electrolytes are being monitored and repleted as needed. His cardiac and diabetic diet is being followed, and he is receiving prophylaxis for DVT and stress ulcer.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Atrial fibrillation: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and the recent episode this morning may indicate a risk of future episodes.
* Respiratory decompensation: The patient's history of asthma and BOOP, as well as his recent respiratory decompensation, may indicate a risk of future respiratory problems.
* Hypotension: The patient's variable blood pressure and recent episode of hypotension may indicate a risk of future episodes.
* Cardiac enzymes: The patient's elevated cardiac enzymes may indicate a risk of cardiac damage or further cardiac complications.
* Esophageal inflammation: The patient's history of esophageal inflammation may indicate a risk of further complications, such as bleeding or perforation.
* DVT and stress ulcer: The patient's prophylaxis for DVT and stress ulcer may indicate a risk of future complications, such as DVT or stress ulcer bleeding.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:15.3/36.7/1.3, CK / CKMB /
   Troponin-T:254/23/0.71, Lactic Acid:1.0 mmol/L, Ca++:8.5 mg/dL,
   Mg++:2.2 mg/dL, PO4:3.0 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   Mr [**Known lastname 3369**] is a 63 year-old man with a history of ischemic
   cardiomyopathy s/p ICD/biV pacer and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation who
   presents with atrial fibrillation resulting in ICD firing in the
   setting of missing his rate control agents.  In sinus rhythm overnight,
   but going into wide complex atrial fib with RVR.
   #) Atrial fibrillation:  Likely triggered by stopping sotalol and
   metoprolol.  Likely the metoprolol had been supressing his sympathetic
   drive recently and prevent recurrent afib.  However, in the setting of
   ambulating on [**9-23**] and no lopressor, he flipped back into it.  Baseline
   rhythm is sinus sensed, v-paced, but pacer turns off at rates >150 and
   his native (LBBB) conduction is exposed.  ICD firing happened because
   of relatively wide complex misrecognized as VT.  He spontaneously
   converted to NSR, reverted to atrial fibrillation, now alternating
   between the two.
   - on verapamil and quinidine gluconate- increased quinidine gluconate
   from q8 to q6hr
   - continue IV verapamil when patient goes into elevated rate
   - Will start metoprolol 25mg [**Hospital1 **] this AM to better control his rate and
   sympathetic drive
   - Daily EKGs to monitor QTc on quinidine
   - on telemetry
   .
   #) Respiratory decompensation:  Pt with history asthma + BOOP,
   initially retaining CO2 on arrival to CCU.  Possibly his broncospasm
   was worsened in the setting of frequent dosing of metoprolol.  He has
   also received repeated doses of Ativan, but his tachypnea argues
   against hypoventilation secondary to depressed drive.  He has also been
   intermittently hypoxic, with questionable aspiration PNA (RLL opacity
   of CXR) +/-some degree of volume overload noted on CXR.  Pt intubated
   on admission to hospital.  Extubated yesterday- did well.  No signs of
   respiratory distress.
   - now off levo given tendency to prolong QT
   - stopped flagyl given unlikeliness of aspiration PNA.
   - discontinued augmentin
   - on RA- satting well.
   - continue home asthma meds (pulmicort, albuterol, montelukast,
   fluticasone)
   #) Hypotension:  Resolved.  BP now in 120s-140s.
   - Restarted home lisinopril 20mg PO daily
   - continue verapamil and start metoprolol 25mg today
   - stress-dose steroids
   #) Pump:  No echo in our system, but by report EF 30%.  Some evidence
   of volume overload on initial CXR, but neither cardiogenic shock nor
   pulmonary edema seem to be the main causes of his decompensation.
   -          ECHO on [**9-24**] shows moderately dilated left ventricle with
   severe global systolic dysfunction. Increased mitral regurgitation with
   atrial fibrillation and rapid ventricular response (175 bpm).  LVEF of
   25-30%.
   -          Lasix 20mg IV for diuresis
   # Coronaries:  Reported "heart attack" [**2156**] with PCI but no
   intervention, unknown findings.  Cardiac enzymes added onto peri-code
   labs and severely elevated, but this was in the setting of multiple ICD
   firings.  EKG without ischemic changes.
   - on ASA
   #) Esophageal inflammation:  Per thoracic surgery, he actually never
   had an esophageal tear, only imflammatory changes.  He has been on
   vanc/levo/flagyl/fluconazole and now off Abx.  Diet recently advanced
   to regular but softs
   - d/c
ed fluconazole one day early due to risk of prolonging QT
   - f/u thoracics recs (following as consults)
   FEN: Monitor and replete lytes PRN, cardiac/diabetic diet
   ACCESS: PIV's
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with heparin SC
   CODE: full code, confirmed with pt's wife

Summary:

The patient, a 63-year-old man with a history of ischemic cardiomyopathy, presents with atrial fibrillation (Afib) and rapid ventricular response (RVR) requiring verapamil and quinidine gluconate. The patient had a brief episode of Afib with RVR this morning, which responded well to verapamil. The patient's medical history includes ischemic cardiomyopathy, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, and a history of asthma and bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP).

The patient's current medications include verapamil, quinidine gluconate, metoprolol, and furosemide. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 68-144 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 123/70 mmHg. The patient's respiratory status is stable, with an oxygen saturation of 91% and a respiratory rate of 15 breaths per minute.

The patient's laboratory results show anemia of chronic disease, with a hemoglobin level of 9.5 g/dL and a hematocrit level of 28.5%. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, with a potassium level of 4.2 mEq/L, a sodium level of 137 mEq/L, and a chloride level of 99 mEq/L.

Potential medical complications:

1. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and rapid ventricular response increases the risk of cardiac arrhythmias, including ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation.
2. Respiratory decompensation: The patient's history of asthma and BOOP increases the risk of respiratory decompensation, including acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
3. Hypotension: The patient's history of hypertension and heart failure increases the risk of hypotension, which can be exacerbated by the use of vasodilators such as verapamil.
4. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's history of electrolyte imbalance increases the risk of electrolyte imbalance, including hyperkalemia and hypokalemia.
5. Infection: The patient's history of infection, including pneumonia and bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia, increases the risk of infection, including sepsis and septic shock.
6. Thrombosis: The patient's history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE) increases the risk of thrombosis, including DVT and PE.
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of gastrointestinal bleeding increases the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, including upper gastrointestinal bleeding and lower gastrointestinal bleeding.
8. Kidney injury: The patient's history of kidney injury increases the risk of kidney injury, including acute kidney injury and chronic kidney disease.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 63-year-old man with a history of ischemic cardiomyopathy, atrial fibrillation, and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. He was admitted to the ICU with atrial fibrillation, which was likely triggered by stopping sotalol and metoprolol. He has been experiencing episodes of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR), which has been treated with verapamil and quinidine gluconate.

The patient has also been experiencing respiratory decompensation, with tachypnea and intermittent hypoxia. He has a history of asthma and bronchiolitis obliterans with organizing pneumonia (BOOP). He was intubated on admission but was extubated yesterday. He has been experiencing some degree of volume overload, which has been managed with diuresis and fluid restriction.

The patient has also been experiencing hypotension, which has been treated with restart of home lisinopril and continued verapamil. He has a history of cardiac enzymes that were severely elevated, but this was likely due to multiple ICD firings.

Other medical issues include esophageal inflammation, which has been managed with antibiotics and diet advancement. The patient has also been experiencing anemia of chronic disease, which is being managed with iron studies and blood transfusions.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Atrial fibrillation: Continued episodes of atrial fibrillation with RVR can lead to heart failure, cardiogenic shock, and even death.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory decompensation can lead to further deterioration, including respiratory failure, which can be life-threatening.
3. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension can lead to organ dysfunction, including kidney failure, liver failure, and even death.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia can lead to fatigue, weakness, and decreased oxygen delivery to tissues, which can exacerbate other medical conditions.
5. Infection: The patient's esophageal inflammation and antibiotic use can increase the risk of infection, including sepsis and septic shock.

To prevent these complications, the patient should continue to receive close monitoring and treatment, including:

1. Atrial fibrillation management: Continue verapamil and quinidine gluconate as needed to manage episodes of atrial fibrillation.
2. Respiratory support: Continue oxygen therapy and non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV) as needed to manage respiratory decompensation.
3. Blood pressure management: Continue verapamil and lisinopril as needed to manage hypotension.
4. Anemia management: Continue iron studies and blood transfusions as needed to manage anemia.
5. Infection prevention: Continue antibiotic prophylaxis and monitor for signs of infection, including fever, chills, and increased white blood cell count.

In conclusion, the patient requires close monitoring and treatment to manage his multiple medical conditions and prevent potential complications.

   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:12.8/58.1/1.1, CK / CKMB /
   Troponin-T:254/23/0.71, Lactic Acid:1.0 mmol/L, Ca++:8.3 mg/dL,
   Mg++:2.0 mg/dL, PO4:2.9 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   Mr [**Known lastname 3369**] is a 63 year-old man with a history of ischemic
   cardiomyopathy s/p ICD/biV pacer and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation who
   presents with atrial fibrillation resulting in ICD firing in the
   setting of missing his rate control agents.  No a-fib events in last 24
   hrs.
   #) Atrial fibrillation:  Likely triggered by stopping sotalol and
   metoprolol.  Likely the metoprolol had been supressing his sympathetic
   drive recently and prevent recurrent afib.  However, in the setting of
   ambulating on [**9-23**] and no lopressor, he flipped back into it.  Baseline
   rhythm is sinus sensed, v-paced, but pacer turns off at rates >150 and
   his native (LBBB) conduction is exposed.  ICD firing happened because
   of relatively wide complex misrecognized as VT.  He spontaneously
   converted to NSR, reverted to atrial fibrillation, now alternating
   between the two.  No a-fib events in last 24 hrs.
   - metoprolol 25mg [**Hospital1 **] started on [**9-26**]
   - on verapamil and quinidine gluconate
   - continue IV verapamil when patient goes into elevated rate
   - Daily EKGs to monitor QTc on quinidine
   - on telemetry
   - will d/c on metoprolol, verapamil and quinidine- f/u with outpatient
   cardiologist to adjust these medications
   .
   #) Respiratory decompensation:  Pt with history asthma + BOOP,
   initially retaining CO2 on arrival to CCU.  Possibly his broncospasm
   was worsened in the setting of frequent dosing of metoprolol.  He has
   also received repeated doses of Ativan, but his tachypnea argues
   against hypoventilation secondary to depressed drive.  He has also been
   intermittently hypoxic, with questionable aspiration PNA (RLL opacity
   of CXR) +/-some degree of volume overload noted on CXR.  Pt intubated
   on admission to hospital, extubated the next day- doing well since.
   - on RA- satting well.
   - on home asthma meds (pulmicort, albuterol, montelukast, fluticasone)
   #) Hypotension:  Resolved.  BP now in 120s-140s.
   - home lisinopril 20mg PO daily
   - continue verapamil and start metoprolol 25mg today
   - stress-dose steroids- on taper now
   #) Pump:  No echo in our system, but by report EF 30%.  Some evidence
   of volume overload on initial CXR, but neither cardiogenic shock nor
   pulmonary edema seem to be the main causes of his decompensation.
   -          ECHO on [**9-24**] shows moderately dilated left ventricle with
   severe global systolic dysfunction. Increased mitral regurgitation with
   atrial fibrillation and rapid ventricular response (175 bpm).  LVEF of
   25-30%.
   -          Lasix 20mg IV for diuresis on [**9-25**], Lasix 40mg PO dose on
   [**9-26**]
   -          goal of making the patient 500cc negative;
   -          Will need lasix 20mg PO daily at home
   # Coronaries:  Reported "heart attack" [**2156**] with PCI but no
   intervention, unknown findings.  Cardiac enzymes added onto peri-code
   labs and severely elevated, but this was in the setting of multiple ICD
   firings.  EKG without ischemic changes.
   - on ASA
   #) Esophageal inflammation:  Per thoracic surgery, he actually never
   had an esophageal tear, only imflammatory changes.  He has been on
   vanc/levo/flagyl/fluconazole and now off Abx.  Diet recently advanced
   to regular but softs
   - f/u thoracics recs (following as consults)
   .
   #) Hyponatremia- Sodium trending down this AM (133
 128).  Most likely
   secondary to lasix administration
   -PM lytes
   FEN: Monitor and replete lytes PRN, cardiac/diabetic diet
   ACCESS: PIV's
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with heparin SC
   CODE: full code, confirmed with pt's wife
   [**Name (NI) **]: with patient's wife [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 3369**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8360**] (other numbers on
   board in room)
   DISPO: CCU for now
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:

   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:

   Comments:
